channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Group From Taiwan Clashes With Kenyan Police Over Deportation to China
item.description: Officers used tear gas to remove 15 people who had barricaded themselves in a jail cell after a fraud trial.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Johnny Chiang, a legislator from the Kuomintang party, with a video clip showing Taiwanese detained at a Kenyan police station, during a news conference in Taipei on Tuesday.

item.title: Australian Mother and 8 Others Face Charges in Lebanon Custody Dispute
item.description: Sally Faulkner had tried to take her two children from her Lebanese ex-husband, officials said. Four television journalists were also among the eight facing charges.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:description: Ali al-Amin with the two children. The children were abducted last week by three “armed persons.” Their mother and eight others face charges.

item.title: Belgium Detains and Charges 2 More Men in Inquiry on Attacks
item.description: There are now 21 people charged in the country in connection with the assaults on Brussels, Paris or both, the federal prosecutor said.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: Police officers during a search in the Etterbeek district of Brussels on Saturday.

item.title: European Union Calls for Big Companies to Disclose More Tax Data
item.description: The proposed rules, in the works before the Panama Papers leak, are intended in some ways to lift the veil on similar types of corporate secrets.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: An Amazon warehouse in Brieselang, Germany. The firm is among several multinational companies that have been the targets of European tax inquiries.

item.title: 13 Arrested in Connection With Fireworks Explosion at Temple in India
item.description: Seven of those were officials at the Puttingal temple, where the death toll from the blasts has risen to 112 people.
item.dc:creator: SUHASINI RAJ and GEETA ANAND
item.media:description: A poster in the Indian state of Kerala shows three of the more than 100 victims of the explosion at Puttingal temple.

item.title: Sinosphere: China’s Top Lawyer in Hong Kong Says Secession Advocates Could Face Prosecution
item.description: Wang Zhenmin, of the law department at Beijing’s Central Liaison Office in Hong Kong, said British colonial legislation was still in force and could be used against activists.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: Wang Zhenmin, center, the legal affairs chief at Beijing’s Central Liaison Office in Hong Kong, after a talk on Tuesday at the Foreign Correspondents’ Club in Hong Kong.

item.title: Taiwan Denies Role in Spy Case Involving U.S. Navy Officer
item.description: The military said it had not received secrets from an American naval officer under investigation on suspicion of providing information to Taiwan or China.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Taiwan’s flag flying on one of its warships. In recent decades, the United States has had very few cases that hinted of intelligence activities by Taiwan.

item.title: The Film ‘Merci Patron!’ Emerges as a Rallying Cry in France
item.description: François Ruffin’s documentary takes on the luxury giant LVMH and its chief executive and billionaire philanthropist, Bernard Arnault.
item.category: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton SA
item.dc:creator: DOREEN CARVAJAL
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: François Ruffin, the director of “Merci Patron!” in Paris.

item.title: U.S. and Philippines, United by China, Ramp Up Military Alliance
item.description: A new agreement will allow the United States to spread more American troops, planes and ships across the island nation than have been here in decades.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: FLOYD WHALEY
item.media:description: Marines from the Philippines during joint exercises with the United States in Antique Province this week.

item.title: Boko Haram Using More Children as Suicide Bombers, Unicef Says
item.description: One of every five bombers deployed in West Africa by Boko Haram in the past two years has been a child, usually a girl, according to a new report.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY
item.media:description: Children in Chibok, Nigeria, last month. One of every five suicide bombers deployed by Boko Haram in the past two years has been a child, a report by Unicef said.

item.title: Vancouver Journal: Chinese Scions’ Song: My Daddy’s Rich and My Lamborghini’s Good-Looking
item.description: Many wealthy Chinese are moving their families and riches to Western cities like Vancouver, where their children show off cars and diamond-encrusted watches.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN
item.media:description: From left, Loretta Lai, Chelsea Jiang and Diana Wang attended a reception at a Lamborghini dealership last month in Vancouver, British Columbia.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Bono: Time to Think Bigger About the Refugee Crisis
item.description: It is time for a Marshall Plan to address the problem.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: BONO

item.title: Navy May Charge Officer With Giving China and Taiwan Secrets
item.description: Lt. Cmdr. Edward C. Lin has been under investigation on suspicion of providing secret information to China and Taiwan, United States officials said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG and HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: Lt. Cmdr. Edward C. Lin of the United States Navy, a native of Taiwan, speaking at a naturalization ceremony in Honolulu in 2008.

item.title: Effort to Impeach Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff Clears Congressional Panel
item.description: Supporters of the Brazilian leader are now scrambling ahead of a floor vote in the lower house of Parliament.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: Opposition and government deputies demonstrate during a panel vote in Brasília on Monday.

item.title: Editorial: Europe’s Urgent Security Challenge
item.description: Long after 9/11, attitudes and structures in Europe still impede counterterrorism cooperation.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Suicides Plague Attawapiskat First Nation in Canada
item.description: Since September, 101 people in a remote aboriginal community have attempted suicide. That’s about 5 percent of its population.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Comedian’s Takedown of Turkish President Tests Free Speech in Germany
item.description: Turkey has asked Germany to prosecute a comedian in accordance with a little-known German law on insulting foreign leaders, placing Chancellor Angela Merkel in a bind.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: The Turkish Embassy has requested that Germany prosecute the television comic and satirist Jan Böhmermann under a little-known law on insulting foreign leaders.

item.title: Light Turnout for Vote in Darfur on Region’s Future
item.description: The referendum on whether the Sudanese region should remain as five semiautonomous states or be made into one has been dismissed by some as a meaningless administrative exercise.
item.dc:creator: ZEINAB MOHAMMED SALIH and JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: Waiting on Monday to cast their ballots in El Fasher, North Darfur, Sudan.

item.title: Israel to Release Palestinian Girl Imprisoned at Age 12
item.description: A girl who confessed to planning a stabbing attack in a West Bank settlement will be released from prison early, the Israeli authorities said Monday.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: New Evidence on When Bible Was Written: Ancient Shopping Lists
item.description: An analysis of handwriting on ancient pottery suggests that literacy may have been more widespread than previously known in the Holy Land around 600 B.C.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Letters inscribed on pottery, known as ostracons, which were unearthed in an excavation of a fort in Arad, Israel, and dated to about 600 B.C., shortly before Nebuchadnezzar’s destruction of Jerusalem.
